utterances: Yup.
UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN #1: Take a look.
Let's see if it's really...
This 7-year-old boy is in foster care, just like a lot of his classmates here at Haven Academy Charter School.
Two-thirds of these elementary students are in the child welfare system, meaning they're in foster care or getting preventive services to keep them at home.
These are kids who have witnessed domestic violence or experienced abuse.
Principal Jessica Nauiokas says her teachers know the cases and receive training in trauma to watch for any signs of behavioral or psychological problems.
Yeah, yeah.
And well, you know, with the big tour like ours...
Yeah, it was huge.
And it is going to be a hard fought battle here in Florida.
It's going to come right down to the wire.
With your support, though, we're going to win, we're going to win for you.
If there was an enthusiasm gap between the Obama and McCain campaigns, Sarah Palin has done a lot to erase it.
At a rally in Estero, on Florida's Gulf Coast Monday, Palin once again showed her ability to pack an arena with thousands of motivated Republicans.
Republicans like Charlene Katauski(ph).
Because I love Sarah.
I think she's excellent and she's with what McCain needs on their ticket.
And I'm excited.
I'm scared but I am excited.
And what's the scary part of it?
If Obama gets in.
That scares the bejesus out of me.
At rallies across Florida this week, Palin made good on her promise to take off the gloves.
In Estero, she heated the crowd nearly to the boiling point with relentless attacks on Obama.
His ties to former Weather Underground member Bill Ayers.
His pledge to cut taxes.
She urged voters not to believe him, even his patriotism.
Our opponent gives speech after speech about the wars that America is fighting and it sure would be nice if just once he'd say he wants America to win.
It was a red meat speech for an appreciative crowd.
Palin's visit to Florida this week was just one part of a GOP plan to motivate it's voters to come out big on election day.
Republican strategists concede they have their work cut out for them.
Discontent with President Bush and the focus on the current financial crisis, they say, make it a difficult environment for Republicans.
To make matters more challenging, Democrats have registered many more new voters this year than Republicans.
Florida Democrats now hold a half-million voter edge over the GOP.
To which Florida Republican party chairman Jim Greer has a quick retort.
Numbers don't vote on election day, people do.
Republicans have a good track record in Florida for getting their people out to vote.
It helped them carry the state for George W.
Bush in 2000 and 2004, to elect Charlie Crist governor and to build majorities in the state legislature.
Greer believes his party will outperform Democrats at the polls this year as well.

And at the end of the day, I believe that although they have succeeded in registering a lot of people, many of their new registrations are not going to turn on election day, and Republicans are going to turn out more, just like we did in 2000 and 2004.
Susan McManus is political science professor at the University of South Florida in Tampa.

She agrees that Republicans in Florida have been exceptionally good at mobilizing their voters, identifying keys slices of the electorate they need to reach and using phone trees and neighborhood groups to get them to the polls.
But she sees a difference in this election.
At this time in 2008, Democrats have pretty much borrowed the Republican strategies for turnout used in '04 and maybe even improved them a bit.
With just 27 days until the election, most polls show Obama leading in Florida.
And he has another advantage as well, money.
He's greatly outspent McCain on staff and television ads.
Although McCain's field director is promising to ramp up an aggressive campaign in the remaining weeks.
The place where the battle will be most intense is Central Florida, the I-4 corridor which runs through Orlando and the Tampa-Saint Petersburg area.
The logic is simple.
Traditionally, Democrats carry South Florida, Republicans take the North.
And whichever party takes the middle part of the state comes out the winner.
Greg Allen, NPR News, Miami.
To Haiti now, which hold its presidential election this Sunday.
And today, long lines formed outside government offices.
Haitians were rushing to collect voter ID cards they had applied for months ago -cards they'll need to vote this weekend.
Several of the leading candidates also held rallies today in the capital.
Their supporters flooded the streets, tying up Port-au-Prince's already snarled traffic.
NPR's Jason Beaubien reports.
(Soundbite of knocking)
(Foreign language spoken)
In the Delmas neighborhood of Port-au-Prince, dozens of people swarm an office where they're trying to get their voting credentials.
Several people say they had been waiting in the scorching sun for hours.
An official comes out and tells everyone in the line behind the building that they have to move to a line in front of the building.
But the mob out front was already so big that it completely blocks the sidewalk.
The people behind the office refused to move.
Yolene Dorvilus, with sweat beading on her brow, is one of them.
(Through Translator) I've been here since 5 o'clock with this receipt so they can give me the ID back, but they never do so.
She says if she doesn't get the ID today, she'll be back to wait tomorrow.
As the election approaches, similar scenes are playing out across Port-au-Prince.
Many of the more one million people left homeless after the January earthquake also lost their documents or had to reapply for an ID with a new address.
(Soundbite of music)
Meanwhile, just a few blocks down the street from this office, a rally for presidential candidate Jude Celestin is blocking one of the main arteries to the airport.
(Soundbite of music)
Young people in yellow T-shirts that say Celestin dance in the intersection.
Celestin is the chosen candidate of current President Rene Preval.
Currently, Celestin runs the Haitian National Construction Company.
His posters are plastered across the capital.
Germana Pascal says he was supporting Haitian American hip-hop star Wyclef Jean until Jean was disqualified.
Now, Pascal is backing Celestin.
(Foreign language spoken)
For Pascal, the most important issue in this election is education.
If we have education, everything else will follow, he says: development, jobs and a country that is better for the youth.
(Soundbite of music)
On the other side of town, supporters of Michel Martelly, known as Sweet Micky, were also massing in the streets.
Martelly is a popular compa musician known for his wild antics on stage.
In this crowd, 34-year-old Obede Derane says he's supporting the Haitian pop star precisely because Martelly has no experience in politics.
Probably not in the near term.
I think North Korea realized that there would be some sanctions.
This may be more than they expected, but they knew something was coming.
And the nuclear weapons program is so important to Kim Jong Il he's clearly willing to take a lot of heat.
But I think it will help to constrain the North Korean procurement of things they need to keep the program going.
And I think it will put the pain on the elite around Kim Jong Il.

Much of this sanction resolution targets financial transactions by any entities believed to be, you know, associated with those nuclear, or other activities, or weapons sale, which is virtually every North Korean entity.
So the cash flow into North Korea, which Kim Jong Il uses to pay off his elite; it's kind of the walk around money for his councillery.
That's going to be constricted and people will notice that their allowance goes down.
It won't cause them to buckle.
It won't cause them to collapse.

But at a time when Kim Jong Il is trying to demonstrate his power and his legitimacy with his nuclear weapons test, this will be a reminder to those around him that things will get tougher the longer they stay on this path.
So, time is an element of sanctions?
Time is an element.
Diplomacy will be an element.
Sanctions in themselves are not going to do what needs to be done.
There will have to be a diplomatic off-ramp.
There will have to be a diplomatic process, in deed, a face-saving way for Kim Jong Il to back down.
And that's not going to happen soon but it's part of the tool kit.
Let's get a caller on the line.
Our number, if you'd like to join the conversation, is 800-989-8255, 800-989.
And the e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
And we'll begin with Peter.
Peter calling us from Berkeley, California.
Hi.
Well, my question was partially answered there and I wish you would elaborate with your guest.

Is there always a clear way out of sanctions for a country like North Korea; a prescription for what they need to do and what they will get - the carrot as well as the stick - and a way to maintain dignity for them?
Maybe - and one idea, just that I'll put out, is six-party talks, fine.
But what's wrong with bilateral?
And also, what's wrong with global talks, you know?

North Korea - just to explain Peter's point - I think has been asking for bilateral or direct bilateral negotiations with the United States, which is willing to do it but only on the margins of the six-party talks.
So anyway, Michael Green.
Well, the diplomatic off ramp, in a way, is already there.
It's the September - the last meeting of the six parties: Japan, The U.S.
ROK, China, Russia, North Korea.

They all agreed, including North Korea, to a process for dismantling all of North Korea's nuclear weapons and programs in exchange for a variety of inducements, including normalization, economic and energy assistance and so forth, and I think when Secretary Rice goes to the region tomorrow she will hear from her Chinese and South Korean counterparts that they would like to see a way to convince North Korea to come back into that process and try to get them to take the deal that was on the table, and I think she'll be inclined to do that at some point.
Right now, I think the administration's focused on demonstrating to North Korea there are consequences for its actions.
Bilateral dialogue was part of that formula and would have been greatly expanded had North Korea followed up on commitments to begin dismantling.

So it's there for the taking if North Korea wants it, but I don't think the administration will or should respond to the North Korean nuclear test by making our opening gambit a delegation to meet with the North Koreans and see what they want.
That would teach them all the wrong lessons.
And ROK, by the way, is Republic of Korea, which we usually refer to as South Korea.
Anyway, Peter, thanks very much for the question.
Can the guest share some specifics about what's in it for North Korea besides the relief of the sanctions - some positive aspects?
